title: PSA: Calling for reports is itself reportable as toxic behavior

embed.description: There has been a wave of posts over the last few days about the confusion that surrounds the reporting system. In particular around report calling.

body:
Right now on the front page alone there are 4 threads in which people asked for reports and don't consider that poor behavior, and I know it's a common thing to do (regardless if the report is deserved or not). So here's a quote from Riot Hursker:

>Calling for others to report a player is a punishable offense. It is a form of bullying and as such is against the summoner code. It should always be a personal decision for each player as to whether or not they feel another player warrants a report. In fact, do feel free to tell your team mates that "report calling" in itself counts as harassment. Flaming and bullying a player will never help them to improve their game mechanics, communication etc.

So if you ever feel the need to say stuff like "x9 this guy" or "report X pls", don't. It counts against you more than against them, and it isn't even needed. What matters is the number of games reported, not the amount of reports per game, so 1 report is as good as 9. If you see somebody behaving in a way you feel it should be reported, report them at the end of the match. That's all. If they are indeed in the wrong they'll be dealt with with your report alone. Getting more people to report somebody won't change anything for them, but it might count against you.

replies.body: You're right about everything except the part where the amount doesn't matter, the amount does actually matter, and a guy will be sooner prosecuted who was reported by 3 or more people than a guy who had 1 report, especially if that happens in several games.
All that matters is the amount of games in which you received at least one report, not the amount of reports. Any report past the first for the same game is redundant.

if multiple reports counted, then people would just queue as 2,3,4,5 in norms and ban people left and right

number of reports in a game doesn't matter, but number of reports on multiple games does.

Also worth noting that over-reporting lowers the weight of reports you give.

If you report someone in half of your games, as an example, the game starts to ignore reports you make assuming that you are just reporting people when you lose or when you have a teammate that makes a misplay.

At one point it was ban able if you report people in too many games where no one deserved a report (a lot of false reports not just a few) but I'm not sure if that still is in place.
